name: Li Ming
bio: With over 20 years of experience he is a master of traditional Chinese cuisine. He specializes in Cantonese-style dishes and is known for his expertise in seafood.

numberRecipes.name: Dumplings
numberRecipes.description: Small, filled pockets of dough that can be steamed, boiled or pan-fried, often served as a snack or appetizer.
numberRecipes.cookingMethod: Dumplings can be cooked in a few different ways, including boiling, steaming, frying, and baking. Boiling is the most common method and involves placing the dumplings in a pot of boiling water and cooking until they float to the surface, which usually takes about 3-5 minutes. Steaming involves using a bamboo steamer to cook the dumplings over boiling water for about 5-10 minutes. Frying involves pan-frying or deep-frying the dumplings until crispy and golden brown. Baking is a less common method that involves brushing the dumplings with oil and baking them in the oven until they are cooked through and golden brown, which usually takes about 15-20 minutes.

numberRecipes.name: Mapo Tofu
numberRecipes.description: A spicy and flavorful Sichuan dish made with tofu, ground pork, and a spicy bean sauce.
numberRecipes.cookingMethod: To make Mapo Tofu, start by browning ground pork in a hot wok or pan, then set it aside. Stir-fry minced garlic and ginger until fragrant, then add chili bean sauce and Sichuan peppercorns. Next, add cubed tofu and a little water or broth, and simmer until the tofu is heated through and the sauce has thickened. Finally, return the ground pork to the wok and stir to combine. Serve hot with steamed rice.

numberRecipes.name: Hot and Sour Soup
numberRecipes.description: A savory soup made with vegetables, tofu, and a tangy, spicy broth.
numberRecipes.cookingMethod: To make Hot and Sour Soup, start by bringing chicken or vegetable broth to a boil in a pot. Then, add sliced mushrooms, cubed tofu, and sliced bamboo shoots to the pot. In a separate bowl, beat eggs and set them aside. Next, add vinegar, soy sauce, and chili oil to the pot, and stir to combine. Slowly pour in the beaten eggs while stirring the soup in a circular motion. Finally, garnish with chopped scallions and serve hot.

name: Chen Wei
bio: He is a rising star in the Chinese culinary world. Despite his relatively short 15 years of experience, he has already made a name for himself with his innovative fusion dishes that blend traditional Chinese flavors with Western techniques.

name: Zhang Lei
bio: Zhang Lei is a veteran chef with 18 years of experience. He is best known for his Sichuan-style cooking, which features bold and spicy flavors.
